title: Monday, 12th June, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
BE11:02am

Off we go then! Welcome to Monday. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily thing with the typing.

BE11:02am

BE11:02am

It's a detail from a plan of a Manrolan Berliner Printing Press, nicked from this brilliant blog:

11:02 am
BE11:02am

https://oatmealent...dian-print-centre/

BE11:02am

(Photo credit: Kirsten Gibbs.)

BE11:03am

And it's included here to mark the news that ...............

11:02 am
BE11:03am

The Guardian is to go tabloid, dropping its distinctive Berliner format and shifting to the smaller print size to try and slash costs.

BE11:03am

https://www.ft.com...-b7ab-88804f3f5b67

BE11:03am

People familiar with plans for the shift at the newspaper have this morning confirmed a report in today’s Daily Telegraph that the Guardian is close to finalising a deal with the Daily Mirror’s parent company Trinity Mirror.

11:03 am
BE11:03am

Staff at the Guardian are now preparing to reformat the newspaper’s pages for the switch, which is part of a wider cost cutting drive to try and stop operating losses which were £38m in 2016/17.

BE11:04am

So, yeah, turns out that your printing presses are a bit underutilised if you publish a paper in a format not used outside Germany.

BE11:04am

That looks quite obvious in retrospect. I wonder who made the decision to .....

11:04 am
BE11:04am

Monday 12 September 2005 was "a historic moment for the Guardian", according to Carolyn McCall, chief executive of Guardian Media Group – and she wasn't wrong. It was the day the paper switched from the traditional broadsheet format to the new Berliner style.

BE11:04am

Oh.

BE11:04am

https://www.thegua...ry-of-the-berliner

11:04 am
BE11:04am

While the Times and Independent had turned tabloid with some success, the format didn't feel right for the Guardian.

BE11:04am

K.

BE11:04am

"We could have gone for a tabloid Guardian straight away," said McCall. "That was the easy option. We pioneered quality tabloid journalism with G2, and the technology was there. But we all felt that was not in the tradition of the Guardian. We are an innovative organisation, and we pride ourselves on being first with new ideas."

11:04 am
BE11:04am

............ Hm. Carolyn McCall. I know that name ........

BE11:05am

McCall continued: "There was a six or seven week period after the Indy [changed to tabloid] when the commercial pressure was to go tabloid, but we resisted that temptation. We sat down and talked, and decided that we had to aim high."

BE11:05am

.............Well resisted, Ms McCall!

11:05 am
BE11:05am

And I'm sure it wasn't too expensive. I mean, they didn't have to buy new presses or anything! It didn't cost, I dunno, £80m or anythi-

BE11:05am

The entire enterprise involved an investment of £80m, of which £50m was spent on brand new, state-of-the-art presses specially commissioned from German engineer Man Roland. Another £30m was ploughed into the construction of new print sites for them in London's Stratford and in Trafford Park in Manchester.

BE11:06am

McCall said at the time: "This has been the most significant investment for [GNM] – not simply in presses and print sites, but in our journalism, design and the way in which we have communicated with our readers.
"With this bold move we will have the most modern and vibrant newspaper in the country alongside the best online newspaper in the world. No other newspaper is so well placed to address the print and internet needs of both readers and advertisers. No other newspaper group has ever achieved the building of a new print centre and the installation of new presses in just 12 months. The editorial ambition, the commitment and the energy shown by every one of our staff, has been phenomenal."

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Carolyn ............ McCall .................... Whatever happened to .. Oh yeah!

BE11:06am

BE11:06am

That's the one.

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Still, I'm sure EasyJet shares can't still be underperforming closest peer Ryanair by about 100% over her tenure ....

BE11:06am

BE11:06am

.... oh.

11:06 am
easyJet plc (EZJ:LSE): Last: 1,336, up 6.67 (+0.50%), High: 1,336, Low: 1,319, Volume: 486.17k
undefined
BE11:07am

Anyway, let's kick on.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

There's politics, of course. So much politics!

BE11:08am

Nick Clegg's op-ed is worth reading, if you haven't: https://www.ft.com...-a3f4-c742b9791d43

BE11:09am

Reader comments are running at about 50% good. Though your opinion on which 50% that is might vary from mine.

11:10 am
BE11:11am

We, however, will get on with the stuff not involving the latest rotation of mediocre suits bickering about how an election result has reinforced their pre-existing opinions. There are lots of places on the internet to talk about that.

BE11:11am

Over here, we have a probable rate hike in the US another extend-and-pretend deal for Greece from Eurogroup.

BE11:11am

We've also got the US tech selloff, which we're following to an extent.

11:11 am
Micro Focus International PLC (MCRO:LSE): Last: 2,426, down 73 (-2.92%), High: 2,471, Low: 2,424, Volume: 146.29k
Sage Group PLC (SGE:LSE): Last: 682.50, down 15 (-2.15%), High: 691.00, Low: 681.00, Volume: 623.63k
Sophos Group PLC (SOPH:LSE): Last: 430.80, down 19.1 (-4.25%), High: 449.80, Low: 422.90, Volume: 328.52k
11:12 am
BE11:12am

(On days like this, I really miss Arm. A Cobol cryogenics lab, a tax return form maker and a virus checker. That's all we have left tech wise in UK PLC.)

BE11:14am

Neil Campling of Northern Trust has sent over his thoughts on Friday's selloff, which I'll share in full because he's a lot smarter than me.

BE11:14am

U.S. tech needed a pullback. After all, the Nasdaq 100 is already (even after Friday’s reversal) up 17.5% YTD. The Index is currently showing an annualised return of 46%. This seems high in isolation but even more so when compared to other indices. It is more than double the return of the S&P 500 (8.7%total return YTD, 21.5% annualised) and multiple times the performance of the small-cap Russell 2000 (4.6% YTD, 11.3% annualised). There is a similar picture in Europe and globally. The Europe 600 Tech Index (SX8P) is +15.2% YTD, +42.5% annualised (Euro return) more than double the Stoxx 600 Index which is +6.8% and 22.5% annualised. The S&P Global 1200 IT Index (SGI) is up 20.7% YTD, more than double the 9.7% performance of the MSCI World Index (USD return). On an annualised basis SGI +57% versus MSCI World +28%. The Nasdaq 100’s annualised return would be the highest since the rebound year of the GFC with +53% return in 2009 after the -42% fall in 2008. (All return data sourced from Bloomberg).

11:14 am
BE11:14am

At the weekend the front page of the WSJ ran with a story of how just five US large cap tech stocks, Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Alphabet and Microsoft accounted for 41% of the S&P 500’s market capitalization gains so far this year (of these five we only have a buy recommendation on Facebook). Many funds have beaten the market due to these returns in what is described as one of the “least creative trades of the year – and one of the most profitable”. Such ease of performance return feels, in many respects, too easy and thus ripe for unwinding.

Many investors we feel bought into the positioning of certain areas of the technology sector very late. We do feel that some subsectors of technology, semiconductors for example, offer greater earnings power than are being afforded by estimates and any broader pullback is one which will create opportunities to add to positions. Things such as the a lack of policy enactment in the US and the political uncertainty in the UK can hardly help short term. It all comes at a time many bears seem to have recently capitulated in many stocks, momentum euphoria reaching fever pitch on some, and these annualised returns on some sectors versus broader indices looking somewhat ridiculous. Some of the liquid, very obvious momentum names can be punished hard when any short term momentum changes, and it can also lead to contagion for others. We see the same as offering opportunities to add to positions in the ones with a very strong earnings cycle and high growth (our global digital names, semiconductors and eGaming stocks for example. But we also feel it is important to differentiate between those who have this earnings power, and those who don’t.

BE11:14am

Whether this pullback is for one day, three days, a month or more, who knows? But the same will provide, in our view, an opportunity to add to positions in the companies which offer differentiation versus peers, or those with earnings power, or, best of all, both. Which stocks then? By region we would highlight in particular the following in technology. Europe: AMS, STMicroelectronics, Infineon, ASML, Melexis, Micro Focus, Ubisoft, Logitech and Sophos. In the U.S.: AMD, Facebook, Applied Materials, Teradyne, Electronic Arts, Activision, Take-Two Interactive and Xilinx. In Asia: Netease, Samsung, TSMC, Renesas, Sunny Optical, Tencent, Alibaba and Baidu.

undefined
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Actually, while on tech, I'm reminded of the latest Premier League viewing figures.

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 974.00, down 6.5 (-0.66%), High: 981.00, Low: 972.00, Volume: 412.25k
BE11:17am

They're terrible.

11:17 am
BE11:18am

https://www.ft.com...-a3f4-c742b9791d43

BE11:18am

Premier League football suffered the biggest drop in viewing on Sky TV for at least seven years, raising questions over the popularity of live sports as well as the sustainability of a lucrative source of funding for English clubs.

Average viewing on Sky’s live TV channels fell 14 per cent over the past season even after it paid two-thirds more to show the matches under the latest three-year deal with the Premier League at about £10m per game.

BE11:18am

.............. Head down to the middle of that story and ......

11:18 am
BE11:18am

Sky said the dip in the average numbers — the worst since Barb established its current audience measurement methods in 2010 — was partly explained by the new rights deal that gave it 10 additional matches featuring smaller, less popular teams.

BE11:19am

I've tried to get my head around the data in the past, and failed. But intuitively, I'm not sure I go along with this idea that "smaller, less popular teams" attract smaller audiences.

BE11:20am

I mean, sure, fewer people support Hull than Manchester Whatever.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

But do Hull supporters watch Manchester Whatever versus Arsenal?

BE11:22am

I figured the model football broadcasting would move towards was pay-per-view, where you charge those keenly interested in one specific game a lot of money rather than the current setup of selling them packages that give them a lot of games in which they have no interest whatsoever.

BE11:22am

I mean, that model's the most valuable for the broadcasters. But it's also the one that's most likely to be eaten by illegal and semi-legal OTA services.

11:22 am
BE11:23am

Have Campling again.

BE11:23am

We see the BARB data as the latest in a long line of statistics which suggest the viewing trends of live action sports is going the same way as other forms of linear TV.

BE11:23am

The Champions League final coverage over the weekend in the US saw flat viewership versus 2016 but down 18% from 2015. (Source: SMW). Major League Baseball, on Fox, over the weekend was down 19% in ratings and 16% in viewership from last year. (Source SBD)
Weekend NASCAR Cup Series racing fell 16% in both ratings and viewership YoY. (Source: SMW). The Champions League final in the UK, averaged just 2.8M TV Viewers (Source: The Times). The only ray of light has been in the NHL Stanley cup finals in which the surprising run of the Nashville Predators has captured interest with a 34% viewership increase in the game 4 final versus last year. (Source SMW).

Our recent global marketing roadshow revealed much investor surprise that live action sports was now seeing negative viewership trends, given that it has oft been referred to as the one area of live TV which should be unaffected by viewing habits and alternative media forms. We feel the genre now suffers from saturation coverage. Sports programming represents an outsized source of costs but has historically been seen as an important lever for subscriptions and distribution. ESPN has long been considered to be the biggest beneficiary of the cable TV bundle. The sports “must have” content has enabled ESPN to negotiate ever higher rates with cable TV providers and then insisting that it’s content be in all of the channel bundles regardless of whether the consumer wants the channel is now faced with falling ratings, accelerating subscriber declines and surging content costs. Whereas others now see this position as an unwanted and unfair “ESPN tax” on their PayTV bundle. The rise of skinny bundles, cord cutting, cord shaving and alternative OTT technologies will likely continue to pressure the Live sports TV industry. We’d much rather invest in the next generation of sports; namely eGaming and eSports.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

That's Northern Trust again. Other investment management and financial services companies are available.

undefined
BE11:25am

Mitie mentioned on the right.

11:25 am
Mitie Group PLC (MTO:LSE): Last: 268.70, up 21.9 (+8.87%), High: 283.90, Low: 258.10, Volume: 6.87m
BE11:26am

Divi scrapped, 2018 guidance approximately where it was expected to be, strategic review quite ambitious.

BE11:26am

2017 results are a jumble, but can be ignored.

11:27 am
BE11:27am

£45m cost-efficiency programme announced.

BE11:27am

But no sign of the property business disposal that was previously flagged.

BE11:27am

Nothing much on IFRS15 either, which looms over the sector like a whatever.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Here's Barclays to summarise.

BE11:28am

MITIE (UW, PT 174p) – FY17 results & strategy update. The provisional findings of Mitie’s Accounting Review were announced on 3rd May with an estimated FY17 impact of £40-50m – today’s results present the final outcome of the Accounting Review at £88m (£10.5m impairment of intangible assets, £20.4m adjustment to accrued income on LT complex contracts, £36.4m write-off trade & other receivables, £21.0m of other items), in addition to the £14m of asset write-offs identified in the January trading update. After adjusting for the Accounting Review, and £36.6m of other one-off charges (includes £15m restructuring costs and Property Management goodwill impairment of £15m) Mitie reported adjusted operating profit of £82m, a decline of 14% vs FY16 (which has been restated from previously reported £128.9m due to the Accounting Review and the disposal of Healthcare) and a margin of 3.8% (FY16 restated: 4.4%). No final dividend has been declared and in perhaps somewhat an understatement, FY17 is described as having been “a challenging year”. Net debt of £147m is broadly in line with the May trading update but with some additional disclosure regarding the benefit of invoice discounting which increased by £28m during FY17 (also disclosed is that FY16 increased by £23m). Following the year-end, Mitie approached its lenders to seek agreement to exempt £40m of asset write-downs from covenant calculations and the results confirm lender approval was received and Mitie remained within covenants. While this is a woeful set of results, we expect management to try and shift the focus today more towards their strategy update – there are no big surprises for us in the key points with a focus on FM, cost savings (£45m) and technology – our view remains that market headwinds may make it difficult to hold onto cost savings, and to drive growth (particularly in the public sector). In addition, the accounting adjustments may not be over yet with the statement reporting that IFRS 15 “will have a material impact on the reported assets and income statement of the Group” with a review currently underway ahead of potential early adoption during FY18. Mar-18F PE 15x.

BE11:29am

Canaccord upgrades.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Mitie’s (MTO.L) full year revenue for the year to March 2017 was in line with expectations, up 0.3% to £2,140m. Adjusted underlying operating profit of £82.0m, however, was towards the top end of the guided range. The reported fully diluted EPS from continuing operations before other items was -5.4p (versus 21.3p the prior year), but excluding one-off items we estimate that the fully diluted EPS was around 15.5p. The DPS was 4p. Net debt fell £147.2m at the year end, versus £178.3m the prior year.
The accounting review has been completed with £34.5m of prior periods adjustments . Within the reported operating loss, £88.3m of one-off items were recognised in FY 2017. The company has published a strategy update which looks set to transform Mitie Group. Apart from a range of customer focused initiatives, aimed at putting customers at the heart of its business and focusing on customer lifetime value, it is implementing cost initiatives (including workflow changes) that should deliver run-rate cost savings of c.£45m but FY 2019, and in-year net cost savings of £10m in FY 2018 and an incremental £15m in FY 2019.
Furthermore, by investing more in technology it should strengthen its product and service offering in terms of integrated value propositions. The strategic initiatives give us confidence that Mitie Group can not only retain its market leading position in the UK facilities management market, but further strengthen it.
We will review are earnings forecast but are likely to keep them broadly unchanged. The shares currently trade on a prospective earnings multiple of 14.2x FY 2018, falling to 12.7x for FY 2018 and 11.1x for 2020E. The strategic review should, in our view, significantly enhance both the competitiveness as well as the profitability of the company. On the back of our DCF mid-range value, based on 1% revenue growth and 4.5% operating margin, we increase our target price to 300p (from 195p) and upgrade our recommendation to BUY (from Hold).

BE11:31am

Hm. I mean, it's good that it doesn't need a cash call. But 15 times (on current price) doesn't seem that much of a bargain at the start of a very, very long journey to stabilise things.

undefined
11:32 am
BE11:32am

ROTR still talking football rights, I see.

BE11:33am

Which reminds me that this turned up in my reader this morning.

BE11:33am

http://www.express...nload-Update-Delay

11:33 am
BE11:33am

That's a story about an update of "the popular media player Kodi"

BE11:02am

Here's a picture.

BE11:34am

Which you'd more regularly associate with stuff about how things might or might not cure your lumbago.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

As was the case with EMI, there's a mainstreaming of this stuff that investors risk seeing rather too late.

BE11:35am

Irrelevant for Sky now, of course, because Murdoch's trying the take-private. But worth bearing in mind for the likes of Pearson and, arguably, for ITV as well.

ITV PLC (ITV:LSE): Last: 184.60, up 0.6 (+0.33%), High: 186.00, Low: 183.00, Volume: 2.05m
11:35 am
Pearson (PSON:LSE): Last: 712.50, down 5 (-0.70%), High: 716.00, Low: 710.50, Volume: 295.88k
undefined
BE11:37am

Here's the GE statement.

11:36 am
BE11:37am

http://www.genewsr...-and-ceo-ge-283823

BE11:37am

Jeff Immelt to Remain Chairman of the Board through December 31, 2017
Jeff Bornstein Named Vice Chair of GE; Continues as CFO
Portfolio Transformation Paves Way for New Leadership
GE’s 2017 Framework Remains Unchanged

BE11:38am

2017 guidance unchanged, one suit swapped for another. I'm sure this is significant but I can't immediately form an argument as to why.

11:38 am
undefined
BE11:39am

Quick wander round sellside, then.

BE11:39am

There's a big med-tech thing out of Citi.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

Including .....

BE11:39am

BE11:40am

No. Just no.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

(@luzh: we've written so much about Kodi here, I'm beginning to bore myself on the theme.)

BE11:40am

Anyway, have the working on that sell call.

BE11:41am

While S&N has done a solid job navigating historical price pressures, we are perplexed at consensus’ expectations for an earnings growth inflection to +8-10%, particularly in the context of little historical growth and challenges (e.g. Medtronic / CJR etc). Trading on 22x PE (16x EBIT, 11x EBITDA) the stock is not especially cheap in absolute terms, or versus peers, and looks a touch overvalued to us, hence we see greater value elsewhere.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

We see challenges on the horizon for S&N, from Medtronic’s entry into the hip & knee market (est. ~2-3% annual earnings risk), to the CJR program (~2% EPS risk from 1.5% hospital pricing pressure), to the expansion of ambulatory surgery centers (~1% EPS risk each year from price risk and increase in sales reps). Individually (and perhaps collectively) we view these challenges as manageable by S&N, our issue is more with expectations.

BE11:41am

Consensus has earnings growth accelerating into the +8-10% range, driven by expectations of improved execution, despite years of no growth and the risks highlighted above. We are c. 5% behind consensus.

BE11:41am

For at least the last 6 years, S&N has not grown earnings (post acquired amortization). Likewise, unlevered free cash flow has been flat over this time. Again, to us this highlights the optimism seen in consensus’ double digit earnings growth forecast.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

S&N is trading above both its own 10-year average on a P/E and EV/EBIT-basis & relative to EU MedTech, as well as having reached parity with the best-in-class Stryker. On 22x FY18E Citi earnings (16x EBIT, 22x NOPAT), we think the stock is starting to look expensive given 3-yr forward EPS CAGR of +3-4%, particularly given expectations (no sell ratings other than Citi).

Smith & Nephew PLC (SN.:LSE): Last: 1,346, down 14 (-1.03%), High: 1,348, Low: 1,337, Volume: 791.69k
BE11:42am

That's part of ....

11:41 am
BE11:42am

BE11:42am

Hey, want to see some photos of wounds, ulcers and sutures?

BE11:42am

Ever seen an arthroscopic view of a steel pin going through a glenohumeral joint?

11:42 am
BE11:43am

Fancy reading a brand-recognition analysis of interventional bladder control treatments?

BE11:43am

I didn't. I really, really didn't. And having read it this morning, I still don't.

BE11:43am

Here's Citi's breakout sum on ConvaTec.

11:43 am
BE11:43am

We initiate on CTEC at Neutral and TP of £3.52. While we see cost savings for +300bps to margins as feasible, and an improvement in ostomy growth, historically poor operating performance, questionable earnings quality (substantial exceptional costs & amortization add-back), and up to date valuation (FY18E 16x EBITDA, 26x reported earnings) leave us neutral on the stock.

BE11:43am

Our work on the margin improvement program (MIP) suggest the planned savings look fair, with required savings of $58mn driven by footprint optimization ($15mn), productivity improvements ($12mn), and sourcing ($19mn). While we question why the asset was IPO’ed before cost savings, and a margin mix comparison to COLOB paints a mixed picture, our work suggests CTEC has a good shot at hitting its +300bps target.

BE11:44am

After years of apparent underinvestment, changes will take time but we do expect a slow and steady improvement in CTEC’s ostomy business, albeit off a low base (organic growth +1.7% FY16A vs. +1.3% FY15A). Similarly, we expect CTEC’s planned push into the intermittent catheter space to add around +30-50bps to group organic growth (c. $5-8mn incremental revenues, 1,000 new patients annually), as the company attempts to take advantage of COLOB’s hydrophilic patent expiry.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

CTEC appears attractive on “underlying” earnings at c. 19x FY18E, or a c. 10-15% discount to EU MedTech. This is after adding back substantial exceptional costs and driven by higher leverage than sector average at 2.2x net debt / EBITDA – on EV/EBITDA at 16x in FY18E CTEC is actually on a c. 30% premium to EU MedTech. Given earnings growth of c. 6%, this doesn’t look very attractive vs. the sector to us.

BE11:44am

Risks
Delivery above below planned MIP savings and a more aggressive turnaround of the ostomy continence franchise are key risks to our rating.

ConvaTec Group PLC (CTEC:LSE): Last: 316.80, down 6.7 (-2.07%), High: 324.70, Low: 315.90, Volume: 877.44k
11:44 am
BE11:44am

There must be easier ways to earn a living than to spend time Excel modelling aggressive turnarounds of ostomy / continence franchises.

undefined
BE11:46am

A source familiar with the situation has been in touch from a beach hut in Mozambique.

11:46 am
BE11:47am

The Berliner move cost more than £160m

£80m for the basic presses, £20m for insertion machines and £60m to Richard Desmond to buy out the printing contract. Plus legal fees etc. Plus print site construction.

BE11:47am

I am, of course, not at liberty to identify my sources.

BE11:47am

(@GBKrona: he seems well.)

11:47 am
undefined
BE11:48am

Oh, and there's Ocado.

Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 282.30, down 7.6 (-2.62%), High: 289.80, Low: 278.00, Volume: 1.00m
11:48 am
BE11:49am

Raising more cash, via senior secured notes.

BE11:49am

£200m apparently. Though I haven't seen that confirmed.

BE11:50am

At nosebleed yield, to flip the revolving credit facility of which £87.5m is drawn

11:50 am
BE11:50am

We also get a 22 week trading update bolted on.

BE11:51am

It says what we know already: volume is ticking along and margin remains terrible.

BE11:52am

One interesting detail that came out of the CFC3 Andover tour last week was that the plant's still only running at 10% capacity or thereabouts .... which means it's having to get its deliveries from CFC2 in Dordon.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Ocado's getting cornflakes delivered to one low-tech warehouse, then freighting them 100 miles down the road to another high-tech warehouse, then packaging them up for distribution from there. Terrific stuff.

BE11:53am

Here's Bernstein.

BE11:53am

In this announcement we see confirmation of the three major parts of our bear thesis. The company is having to raise financing to fund further growth, orders per week is slowing down and EBITDA is in line with our bear expectations. We rate Ocado underperform with a price target of £1.90.

11:54 am
undefined
BE11:55am

Acacia, then.

Acacia Mining PLC (ACA:LSE): Last: 273.50, down 26.6 (-8.86%), High: 306.00, Low: 258.40, Volume: 1.67m
11:55 am
BE11:55am

“The committee has established that Acacia Mining has been conducting its mining business here in Tanzania contrary to the law,” Chairman of a committee ordered by President John Magufuli to conduct an audit of mineral exports over the past 19 years said today.

BE11:56am

It's looking ever more like a siege. Can Tanzania hold out longer than Acacia?

BE11:58am

This is post Reuters reporting last week that Tanzania might put a 1% clearing fee on exports starting July.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

Course, with both reports now out the ball now passes to Acacia to negotiate with government. Difficult to see a near-term resolution though.

undefined
BE12:00pm

Midday, yes, but a couple of things to round up with nevertheless.

12:00 pm
BE12:01pm

Berenberg selling TalkTalk because it's TalkTalk.

BE12:01pm

Continued uncertainty and increasing competition: We think the UK telecoms market faces continued uncertainty and gradually intensifying competition due to several factors. The recent period of regulatory uncertainty has a way to go, with the impact of Ofcom’s various proposals yet to be felt in sector financials. There is major uncertainty over investment, with BT seeming to offer a grand bargain of significant investment in real fibre in return for certain, clear and fair regulation, which may be difficult to achieve. We think competition will gradually intensify in both consumer broadband and mobile markets, with more jostling for position between operators, and less scope to raise prices, in our view. Against this backdrop, our survey of 5,000 UK consumers gives good insights into which operators face challenges and which are well positioned.

BE12:01pm

Vodafone and Virgin Media rank well in our consumer broadband survey, while TalkTalk ranks poorly: Vodafone seems well positioned to gain more broadband share and Virgin Media ranks well in our broadband survey, despite its footprint expansion problems. Our survey suggests there are good reasons for Virgin Media to press on with its footprint expansion. In contrast, TalkTalk does poorly in our broadband survey on many measures. BT (aggregating BT/EE/Plusnet) ranks about mid-table. Our survey confirms BT’s problems are about service rather than network, so BT’s investment in improving customer “experience” is justified.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

Tesco and O2 rank well in our consumer mobile survey, while Vodafone and TalkTalk rank poorly: Other operators could learn a lot from Tesco Mobile, which scores well in several key areas. O2 is the preferred destination for other mobile providers’ churning customers, while also scoring well on several other criteria, despite the consensus view that O2 has under-invested and needs more spectrum. More spectrum will become available in due course, and so far O2’s lack of a convergence offer has not affected its relative performance, while its strong wholesaling position provides a hedge against increased consumer competition. Vodafone UK and TalkTalk rank poorly in our mobile survey for different reasons and both look exposed to customers’ underlying churn intentions, which may hold back TalkTalk’s margins and could delay UK margin recovery for Vodafone.

Talktalk Telecom Group PLC (TALK:LSE): Last: 170.30, down 1.5 (-0.87%), High: 171.90, Low: 166.20, Volume: 715.22k
BE12:03pm

UK broadband market growth set to slow, while UK mobile market service revenues face another year of regulatory drags: UK broadband additions are slowing, but we still think the market has further growth potential to c29m connections by 2026. That means there are another 3.6m broadband connections to fight for. We think BT, TalkTalk and Sky will cede broadband share to Virgin Media, Vodafone and smaller fibre players in the long-term. In the UK mobile market, we expect to see another year of service revenue decline as EC roaming rules affect (c2ppt) this year, but then we expect a return to very modest singledigit mid-term service revenue growth. We think the pre-to post-paid mix-shift will continue, with the UK post-paid base growing by 10m to 64m SIMs (76% of the base) over the next 10 years. With the exception of Three, we expect a gradual shift of service revenue share from mobile network operators (MNOs) to MVNOs like Tesco Mobile, Sky Mobile and Virgin Media.

Buy Vodafone, Hold BT, Sell TalkTalk: We downgrade our TalkTalk EBITDA estimates (by 13-19% for FY 2018-20), price target (by 37% to 140p) and rating to Sell. We maintain our Hold rating on BT but cut our EBITDA estimates (by 1-2% for FY 2018-20) and reduce our price target to £3.25 (from £3.43). We retain our Buy rating on Vodafone, increasing our price target modestly to £2.59, with the shares remaining our favoured UK telco stock.
